10.41.text:
to find out about all the
different efforts within the UK

15.12.text:
Things I didn't know
about, and thinking

17.11.text:
about how everything
links up together--

19.40.text:
from energy, to connect to
grid, to end-to-end platforms,

24.98.text:
So, yeah, that's for me
been the value of today.

27.86.text:
I think everyone's going
to go back and foresee

32.58.text:
their own agendas
and advance things.

36.69.text:
It's clear that there's
a lot of innovation

39.03.text: in this space in the UK.

40.99.text:
And events like
this can help bridge

43.35.text:
those different companies and
efforts, between the policy

48.99.text:
and the industrial efforts and
the academic efforts as well.

57.37.text:
I think there's a lot of
challenges for Internet

59.37.text:
of Things at the moment
in really achieving

61.28.text:
the large roll out and
therefore the value in scale

72.09.text:
You can't change batteries
on this huge array of stuff.

75.06.text:
It's already enough
of a [? pain ?]

76.52.text:
changing batteries on the
things you have in your house.

79.92.text:
So energy harvesting is a
really interesting space.

85.45.text:
harvesting on one side, and
also lower and low-power radios

89.81.text:
and processing and
devices on the other side.

93.74.text:
That will be interesting
where those intersect.

96.03.text:
Also there's been a lot of
talk today about the networking

100.07.text:
It's all very well gathering
data on these devices,

102.20.text:
but again, you don't want
to go round and get data

104.13.text: off every single one of them.

105.42.text:
So how do you get these
things to talk to each other?

109.59.text:
There's lots of local
networks that work well.

113.36.text:
So, Wi-Fi Direct and
BLE are very promising.

116.59.text:
But for the wide
scale, I don't think

118.48.text:
it's clear yet what will
work on a world scale,

121.12.text:
whether it be the stuff
the [? Neal's ?] doing,

123.19.text:
or the stuff that
Telefonica is doing,

126.10.text:
or other people in
the cellular space.

135.01.text:
I think if you look
at the cost to get

137.76.text:
a bit of data a
particular distance,

142.10.text:
enough distance to get back
to a reasonable grid of base

148.99.text:
We should be able to do it on
the back of energy harvesting

153.46.text:
So the question is, can we
as a country and as a world

157.98.text:
come up with technologies
that can help achieve that?

163.13.text:
Right now a lot of the protocol
stacks in many of these devices

166.47.text:
take up a lot of energy
just to climb up the stack.

170.06.text:
And it's reasonably far
removed from the actual cost

174.44.text:
of sending it over
the wireless spectrum.

182.00.text:
To Mark's answer to the
question of how do we--

184.56.text:
how does the government
facilitate this is first off,

188.06.text:
should government just
stay out of the way?

189.85.text: And I think largely that's true.

191.18.text:
But I think the
innovation in this space

194.87.text:
We're doing a lot of
work in this space,

196.54.text: and there's a lot going on.

197.83.text:
But there's also a huge amount
going on in small companies,

202.87.text:
particularly with efforts
like Kickstarter and Indiegogo

211.50.text:
That, I think, is
really exciting.

212.92.text:
So something as simple
as the peer-to-peer ISIS

216.18.text:
will allow us as a country
to fund more start ups.

219.36.text:
And I think that's where the
action should be focused.

222.16.text:
And to maybe helping that
is what government can do.
